text.p: These are the highlights in the Bosnian press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- The ruling Moslem Party of Democratic Action (SDA) says it will not try to exert influence over developments in the Serb entity, but hopes the current political crisis will be overcome and there will be democratisation in the region.

- Bosnian officials returned from a donors' conference in Brussels saying that the international community proved it was committed to helping the country by pledging $1.2 billion in aid, even though the amount fell short of goal set beforehand. The EU offered the largest donation.

- Moslem chairman of Bosnian presidency, Alija Izetbegovic, received an honorary doctorate in law from Mamara University in Istambul citing his contribution for protection of human rights and the establishment of peace in Bosnia.
- Import privileges will remain valid only for war invalids who are 70 percent disabled or more after July 31, when all import privileges are due to expire.

- The main principle in the distribution of funds pledged at the donors' conference in Brussels, will be compliance with the Dayton peace treaty, says the office of the international High Representative to Bosnia.

- Bosnia foreign minister, Jadranko Prlic, and European Union foreign affairs commissioner Hans van den Broek, signed on Thursday in Brussels a memorandum on E.U. aid to Bosnia in 1997. --Sarajevo newsroom +387-71-663-864
